pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:0.5: 25. The training rule on taking back a robe
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.2: Venerable Upananda the Sakyan said to his brother’s student,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.7: And he gave him a robe.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.9: that the Buddha was about to go wandering the country.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.11: “Now I’ll go wandering with the Buddha instead.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.14: he replied, “I’m not going with you, but with the Buddha.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.15: “Well, that robe I gave you is going with me,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.16: and he just took it back in anger.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.17: That monk told other monks what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.18: And the monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.19: “How could Venerable Upananda give away a robe and then take it back in anger?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.20: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.21: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.24: “Foolish man, how could you do this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.26: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.27.1: ‘If a monk himself gives a robe to a monk, but then, in anger, takes it back or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.10: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be assigned to another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.14: if he takes it back himself, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.16: if he asks another, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.17: If he only asks once, then even if the other takes back many, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.18: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.19: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.20: (To be expanded as in Relinquishment 1, with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.21: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I took back after giving it to a monk, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.24: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.25.1: If the other person is fully ordained and he perceives them as such, and after giving them robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.26: If the other person is fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, and after giving them robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.27: If the other person is fully ordained, but he does not perceive them as such, and after giving them robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.28: If, after giving them another requisite, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.29: If, after giving robe-cloth or another requisite to a person who is not fully ordained, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.30: If the other person is not fully ordained, but he perceives them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.31: If the other person is not fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.32: If the other person is not fully ordained, and he does not perceive them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.34: if the other person gives it back;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.35: if he takes it on trust from them;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.37: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.38: The training rule on taking back a robe, the fifth, is finished.
